question:

question:

question:
Select the option that expresses the given sentence in past tense form.
The declarations which come out from that office are not dependable.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 17 July Shift-4)
option_1: The declarations which come out from that office were not dependable.
option_2: The declarations which came out from that office are not dependable.
option_3: The declarations which came out from that office were not dependable.
option_4: The declarations which will come out from that office may not be dependable.
solution:
Answer: The declarations which came out from that office were not dependable.
Solution:

  • The original sentence is in present tense:
    "The declarations which come out from that office are not dependable."

  • To convert it into past tense, both the main verb and the helping verb must be changed:

  • come out â†’ came out (past tense of â€œcomeâ€)

  • are â†’ were (past tense of â€œareâ€)

  • Correct past tense version:
    "The declarations which came out from that office were not dependable."

  • Therefore, the correct option is: The declarations which came out from that office were not dependable.

question:

question:

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
I will not go out if iÌ²sÌ² Ì²rÌ²aÌ²iÌ²nÌ²iÌ²nÌ²gÌ².

solution:
Answer: it rains

    If + present simple, will + base verb

  • Original sentence: "I will not go out if is raining." â€” incorrect because it's missing the subject and uses the wrong tense.

  • Correct version: "I will not go out if it rains."

  • Other options:

  • raining â€“ incomplete, lacks subject

  • will rain â€“ Type 1 condition uses present tense, not future after "if"

  • rained â€“ past tense, which fits Type 2 conditionals, not correct here

  • âœ… Therefore, the correct substitution is: it rains.

question:

question:

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select â€˜No substitution requiredâ€™.

 The correct structure for referring to a state that began in the past and continued up to another point in the past is past perfect:

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select â€˜No substitution requiredâ€™.
In the olden days, many pÌ²eÌ²oÌ²pÌ²lÌ²eÌ² Ì²uÌ²sÌ²eÌ² Ì²tÌ²oÌ² Ì²tÌ²hÌ²iÌ²nÌ²kÌ² that the earth was flat.

Explanation:

Correct Answer: people used to think

ğŸ” Whatâ€™s the grammatical issue?

  • Error Type: Verb form error (tense)

  • Part of speech affected: Auxiliary verb â€œused toâ€

ğŸ“˜ Rule: â€œUsed toâ€ vs. â€œUse toâ€

  • The correct form for expressing a past habitual action is:
    ğŸ‘‰ â€œused toâ€ âœ…

  • âŒ â€œuse toâ€ is incorrect unless following "did" (which is not the case here).

âœ… Correct Sentence:

â€œIn the olden days, many people used to think that the earth was flat.â€

âŒ Evaluation of Other Options:

  • people were used to think â€“ âŒ

  • "Were used to" is followed by noun/gerund, not a base verb

  • Example: She was used to cooking âœ… (not to think)

  • people were thinking â€“ âŒ

  • Continuous tense changes the meaning (temporary action)

  • No substitution required â€“ âŒ

  • The phrase â€œuse toâ€ is incorrect spelling and must be corrected

ğŸŸ¢ So, the correct substitution is: people used to think,

because it correctly expresses a past habit using the proper verb form.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Abu said that hÌ²eÌ² Ì²sÌ²aÌ²wÌ² Ì²tÌ²hÌ²eÌ² Ì²pÌ²iÌ²cÌ²tÌ²uÌ²rÌ²eÌ².

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 2 Dec Shift-1)
option_1: he would have seen the picture
option_2: he will have seen the picture
option_3: he has seen the picture
option_4: he had seen the picture
solution:
Correct Answer:he had seen the picture

Explanation:
The sentence is in reported (indirect) speech, and the reporting verb "said" is in the past tense. So, the verb in the reported clause (he saw) needs to follow the rule of backshifting â€” changing simple past to past perfect.

  • Direct speech: Abu said, "I saw the picture."

  • Indirect speech: Abu said that he had seen the picture.

Letâ€™s evaluate the options:

  • he had seen the picture âœ… â€“ correct backshift from "saw" to "had seen"

  • he would have seen the picture âŒ â€“ changes the meaning and tense

  • he will have seen the picture âŒ â€“ incorrect future perfect; does not follow tense sequence

  • he has seen the picture âŒ â€“ present perfect; does not agree with past reporting verb

Thus, the grammatically correct and contextually accurate form is: he had seen the picture.

question:

  • is gone is informal and not grammatically standard in this context.

Thus, the sentence should read:
â€œOne of my friends has gone to Goa for a holiday.â€

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select â€˜No substitution requiredâ€™.
AÌ²sÌ² Ì²IÌ² Ì²aÌ²mÌ² Ì²hÌ²eÌ²aÌ²rÌ²iÌ²nÌ²gÌ² the lecture it reminded me of a book I had read two years ago.

solution:
Explanation:

Correct Answer: As I heard

ğŸ” Whatâ€™s the grammatical issue?

  • Error Type: Tense mismatch

  • Part of speech affected: Verb phrase (tense/form of â€œhearâ€)

ğŸ“˜ Rule:

  • In English, â€œhearâ€ is a non-continuous verb, which is rarely used in the present continuous form (â€œam hearingâ€) unless for specific emphasis (e.g., â€œIâ€™m hearing strange noisesâ€).

  • Also, the sentence uses â€œremindedâ€ (past tense), so to match the timeline, the hearing action must also be in the past.

ğŸ” Corrected sentence:

â€œAs I heard the lecture, it reminded me of a book I had read two years ago.â€
âœ” This maintains tense consistency (simple past + past perfect).

âŒ Evaluation of Other Options:

  • As I have heard â€“ âŒ
    âœ– Present perfect is mismatched with â€œremindedâ€ (past)

  • When I hear â€“ âŒ
    âœ– â€œHearâ€ is in present simple, inconsistent with â€œremindedâ€ (past)

  • No substitution required â€“ âŒ
    âœ– â€œam hearingâ€ is both tense-wise incorrect and unnatural

ğŸŸ¢ So, the correct substitution is: â€œAs I heardâ€,to ensure the sentence uses past tense consistently and avoids incorrect use of a non-continuous verb.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If no substitution is required, select â€˜No substitutionâ€™.
The warden punished the students wÌ²hÌ²oÌ² Ì²vÌ²iÌ²oÌ²lÌ²aÌ²tÌ²eÌ²sÌ² the rules of the hostel.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 23 August Shift 2 (12 to 1 PM))
solution:
Answer: who violated
Solution:
â€¢ The sentence is in past tense ("The warden punished"), so the relative clause must also match this tense.
â€¢ The correct verb form is "violated" (past tense of â€œviolateâ€) to maintain consistency with the main verb â€œpunishedâ€.
â€¢ Correct sentence: "The warden punished the students who violated the rules of the hostel."

Why the other options are incorrect:
â€¢ who is violating â€“ present continuous tense; doesnâ€™t match with the past action "punished".
â€¢ No substitution â€“ incorrect because "violates" is present tense singular, while "students" is plural and the main verb is past.
â€¢ who are violate â€“ grammatically incorrect; wrong verb form ("are violating" would be correct structure if present continuous were needed).

question:
Select the correct option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
He hÌ²aÌ²dÌ² Ì²gÌ²iÌ²vÌ²eÌ²nÌ² Ì²mÌ²eÌ² that book in 1999.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 25 July Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: gave me
Solution:

  • The original phrase â€œhad given meâ€ is past perfect tense, which is correct in some contexts but may be unnecessarily complex here.

  • The sentence talks about a specific time in the past (1999), so simple past tense is more appropriate: â€œgave meâ€. âœ…

  • Option meanings:

  • Was given me â€“ incorrect passive form for this sentence âŒ

  • Gave me â€“ simple past tense, correct here âœ…

  • Did given me â€“ grammatically incorrect âŒ

  • Gives me â€“ present tense, incorrect for past time âŒ

question:
Select the option that expresses the given sentence in past tense form.
The methods Arunima adopts for taming the dogs create awe and wonder among them.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 26 July Shift-2)
option_1: The methods Arunima adopted for taming the dogs create awe and wonder among them.
option_2: The methods Arunima adopted for taming the dogs created awe and wonder among them.
option_3: The methods Arunima adopts for taming the dogs will create awe and wonder among them.
option_4: The methods Arunima adopts for taming the dogs created awe and wonder among them.
solution:
Answer: The methods Arunima adopted for taming the dogs created awe and wonder among them.
Solution:

  • To express the sentence entirely in the past tense, both verbs should be in the past:

  • adopted (past tense of adopt)

  • created (past tense of create)

  • Option 2 correctly uses both past tense verbs. âœ…

  • Other options either mix tenses or use future tense.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the words in the brackets in the given sentence.
Ten years have passed since my father (is dead).

(SSC SP Ph-11 : 28 June Shift-2)
solution:
The correct answer is died.

Using "died" maintains the correct tense consistency and effectively communicates that the father's death occurred in the past without implying any further past action before that event. Therefore, "died" is the appropriate choice to substitute the words in the brackets in the given sentence.

question:

I aÌ²mÌ² Ì²bÌ²eÌ²eÌ²nÌ² Ì²wÌ²oÌ²rÌ²kÌ²iÌ²nÌ²gÌ² Ì²hÌ²eÌ²rÌ²eÌ² for the past ten years.

solution:
Correct Answer: have been working here

Explanation:
The correct form for the present perfect continuous tense with â€œIâ€ is have been + verb-ing. So instead of â€œam been working,â€ we use â€œhave been working.â€

  • present perfect continuous tense means an action that started in the past and is still ongoing (à¤à¤• à¤•à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤¾ à¤œà¥‹ à¤…à¤¤à¥€à¤¤ à¤®à¥‡à¤‚ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥‚ à¤¹à¥à¤ˆ à¤”à¤° à¤…à¤­à¥€ à¤¤à¤• à¤œà¤¾à¤°à¥€ à¤¹à¥ˆ).

Thus, the sentence should read:
â€œI have been working here for the past ten years.â€

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
During my Goa tour, I hÌ²aÌ²dÌ² Ì²vÌ²iÌ²sÌ²iÌ²tÌ²eÌ²dÌ² beaches in Vasco, Baga and Vagator.

solution:
Answer: visited

  • The phrase â€œDuring my Goa tourâ€ refers to a specific time in the past, so the simple past tense is appropriate.

  • Visited correctly places the action within that past timeframe.

  • The past perfect had visited would imply an action completed before another past action, which isnâ€™t needed here.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Donâ€™t disturb the boy, he pÌ²rÌ²eÌ²pÌ²aÌ²rÌ²eÌ²sÌ² for his examination.

solution:
Answer: is preparing

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Biden wÌ²rÌ²iÌ²tÌ²eÌ² Ì²aÌ² Ì²lÌ²eÌ²tÌ²tÌ²eÌ²rÌ² to the Russian President to restrain from war.

solution:
Answer: wrote a letter

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select 'No improvement required'.
Lily hÌ²aÌ²sÌ² Ì²dÌ²eÌ²dÌ²iÌ²cÌ²aÌ²tÌ²eÌ² her life towards becoming a doctor.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 5 Oct Shift-2 (12_30 to 2_30 PM))
solution:
The option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence is: has dedicated

In the original sentence, "has dedicated" is the correct form of the verb for the present perfect tense. "Dedicated" is the past participle form of the verb "dedicate."

So, the corrected sentence would be: "Lily has dedicated her life to becoming a doctor."

question:
Select the word segment that substitutes (replaces) the bracketed word segment correctly and completes the sentence meaningfully:
Unless you (do will not prepare) well you will not perform well.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 5 Oct Shift-3 (4 to 6 PM))
solution:
The correct word segment that substitutes the bracketed word segment "do will not prepare" correctly and completes the sentence meaningfully is: "prepare"

When "unless" is used to introduce a condition, the verb following it is typically in the simple present tense.

Therefore, the correct answer is: "Unless you prepare well, you will not perform well."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
NÌ²oÌ² Ì²sÌ²oÌ²oÌ²nÌ²eÌ²rÌ² Ì²dÌ²iÌ²dÌ² Ì²hÌ²eÌ² Ì²fÌ²iÌ²nÌ²iÌ²sÌ²hÌ²eÌ²dÌ² his examination than he left for his cricket training centre.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 5_Sept_Shift-2)
option_1: no sooner than he did finished
option_2: no sooner did he finish
option_3: no sooner had he finish
option_4: no sooner than he finished
solution:
Answer: Option 2 â€“ no sooner did he finish

Solution:

The sentence is:
"No sooner did he finished his examination than he left for his cricket training centre."

This is an example of an inversion structure used with "No sooner".
The correct structure is:
ğŸ‘‰ No sooner + did + subject + base form of verb + than...

Let's analyse the options:

  • Option 1 â€“ no sooner than he did finished âŒ
    Incorrect word order and "did finished" is wrong (should be base form after "did").

  • Option 2 â€“ no sooner did he finish âœ…
    Perfect structure: "did + subject + base verb" (did he finish)

  • Option 3 â€“ no sooner had he finish âŒ
    "Had" takes past participle, but "finish" is base form â€“ incorrect.

  • Option 4 â€“ no sooner than he finished âŒ
    Incorrect because inversion is missing; doesn't follow the correct grammatical structure.

So, the correct substitution is no sooner did he finish â€“ Option 2.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select â€˜No substitutionâ€™.
I hÌ²aÌ²vÌ²eÌ² Ì²rÌ²eÌ²aÌ²cÌ²hÌ²eÌ²dÌ² Ì²tÌ²hÌ²eÌ² Ì²hÌ²oÌ²tÌ²eÌ²lÌ², by the time you call me.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 6 Dec Shift-1)
option_1: will be reaching the hotel
option_2: will have reached the hotel
solution:
Answer: will have reached the hotel

Explanation:

  • The sentence talks about an action completed before another future action.

  • The correct tense for this is future perfect: â€œI will have reached the hotel, by the time you call me.â€

  • â€œHave reachedâ€ (present perfect) is not correct for this context.

  • The other options either change the intended meaning or do not use the proper tense.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
She acted aÌ²sÌ² Ì²iÌ²fÌ² Ì²sÌ²hÌ²eÌ² Ì²iÌ²sÌ² the one who was hurt.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 6 Dec Shift-3)
option_3: as if she has been
option_4: as if she will be
solution:
Answer: as if she was

Explanation:

  • After â€œas if,â€ we generally use the past tense to describe something that is imaginary or contrary to fact.

  • â€œas if she isâ€ (present) is incorrect here; it should be â€œas if she wasâ€ (past).

  • The other options (â€œwould,â€ â€œhas been,â€ â€œwill beâ€) do not fit the standard usage with â€œas if.â€

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
She wÌ²iÌ²lÌ²lÌ² Ì²hÌ²aÌ²nÌ²dÌ²lÌ²iÌ²nÌ²gÌ² the baby as tenderly as possible.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 6_Sept_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: Option 4 â€“ will handle

Solution:

The sentence is:
"She will handling the baby as tenderly as possible."

This is incorrect because:

  • After a modal verb like "will", we always use the base form of the verb (V1), not the -ing or past forms.

  • So, "will handling" is wrong; it should be "will handle."

Analyse the options:

  • shall handles âŒ â€“ Incorrect modal and incorrect verb form

  • wills handle âŒ â€“ "Wills" is not a valid modal; grammatically incorrect

  • will handled âŒ â€“ Past form used incorrectly after "will"

  • will handle âœ… â€“ Correct modal + base verb combination

So, the correct substitution is will handle â€“ Option 4.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
You are always tÌ²rÌ²yÌ² Ì²wÌ²iÌ²tÌ²hÌ² Ì²jÌ²uÌ²mÌ²pÌ² over the wall.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 6_Sept_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: Option 1 â€“ trying to jump

Solution:

The sentence is:
"You are always try with jump over the wall."

This is grammatically incorrect because:

  • After "are always", we need the present participle form (verb+ing) â†’ "trying"

  • The correct structure is "try to + base verb" â†’ "trying to jump"

  • The phrase "with jump" is wrong; it should be "to jump"

Correct sentence:

"You are always trying to jump over the wall."

Analyse the options:

  • trying to jump âœ… â€“ Correct structure

  • try to jump âŒ â€“ Incorrect tense; should be â€œtryingâ€ with â€œare alwaysâ€

  • trying in jumping âŒ â€“ Grammatically incorrect phrase

  • tried with jump âŒ â€“ Incorrect tense and structure

So, the correct substitution is Option 1 â€“ trying to jump.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select â€˜No substitution requiredâ€™.
When Rajesh was going to college, he mÌ²eÌ²eÌ²tÌ² with an accident.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 6_Sept_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: (3) met
Solution:
â€¢ The sentence is in the past tense, as indicated by the phrase "was going to college"
â€¢ Therefore, the verb "meet" must also be in the simple past form, which is "met"
â€¢ The phrase "meet with an accident" is correct in structure, but the verb should match the past context

Correct sentence:
"When Rajesh was going to college, he met with an accident."

Other options explained:
â€¢ has met â€“ present perfect tense, does not match the past continuous "was going" âŒ
â€¢ meets â€“ simple present tense, not suitable here âŒ
â€¢ No substitution required â€“ incorrect because "meet" is the base form, not past tense âŒ

So, the correct substitution is (3) met âœ…

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select â€˜No substitutionâ€™.
NÌ²oÌ² Ì²sÌ²oÌ²oÌ²nÌ²eÌ²rÌ² Ì²dÌ²iÌ²dÌ² Ì²tÌ²hÌ²iÌ²sÌ² Ì²iÌ²dÌ²eÌ²aÌ² Ì²eÌ²nÌ²tÌ²eÌ²rÌ² his head, than it carried conviction with it.

solution:
Answer: No substitution

Explanation:

  • None of the alternatives match the idiomatic pattern or tense:

  • â€œhasâ€¦enterâ€ and â€œdoâ€¦enterâ€ are ungrammatical.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
He wÌ²iÌ²lÌ²lÌ² Ì²tÌ²aÌ²lÌ²kÌ² Ì²aÌ²bÌ²oÌ²uÌ²tÌ² nothing but films.

solution:
Answer: talks about

Explanation:
The original â€œwill talk aboutâ€ implies a future action, but the sentence describes a habitual tendency, so the present simple â€œtalks aboutâ€ is correct.

  • Talk about is the standard verbâ€“preposition pairing for discussing topics.

  • Subjectâ€“verb agreement requires talks (he) in the present tense.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
When the weather is hot, IÌ² Ì²wÌ²iÌ²lÌ²lÌ² Ì²lÌ²iÌ²kÌ²eÌ² Ì²tÌ²oÌ² Ì²eÌ²aÌ²tÌ² ice cream.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 9 Nov Shift-1)
option_1: I shall like to eat
option_3: I should like to eat
solution:
Answer: 4 (I like to eat)

Solution (Correct Option - 4: I like to eat):
The sentence is talking about a general habit or preference when the weather is hot. In such cases, we use the simple present tense to express general truths or habitual actions.

The correct structure is:
When the weather is hot, I like to eat ice cream.
âœ” "Like" is in the present tense, and fits naturally with the present time clause "when the weather is hot".

Why other options are incorrect:
I shall like to eat â€“ sounds too formal and futuristic; doesn't express a present habit.
I liked to eat â€“ past tense, but the sentence is about a present/future situation.
I should like to eat â€“ formal British usage, but not suitable in this casual context.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select â€˜No substitution requiredâ€™.
As Simon had already been to the park, he Ì²lÌ²eÌ²aÌ²dÌ² Ì²tÌ²hÌ²eÌ² Ì²wÌ²aÌ²yÌ² for the other children.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 9 Nov Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: 2 (led the way)

Solution (Correct Option - 2: led the way):
The verb â€œleadâ€ is in the present tense, while the sentence is in the past tense (â€œSimon had already beenâ€¦â€). Therefore, the correct past tense form â€œledâ€ should be used.

âœ” Correct sentence:
As Simon had already been to the park, he led the way for the other children.

Why other options are incorrect:
Lead away â€“ means to take someone away from a place, which changes the meaning.
No substitution required â€“ incorrect because â€œleadâ€ (present) does not match the past context.
Leading the way â€“ present participle, doesn't fit with past perfect structure in the sentence.

Difficult Word Meanings:
Lead (verb, present) â€“ to guide or show the way (à¤¨à¥‡à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤µ à¤•à¤°à¤¨à¤¾)
Led (verb, past) â€“ past tense of â€œleadâ€ (à¤¨à¥‡à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤µ à¤•à¤¿à¤¯à¤¾)
Lead away â€“ to guide someone away from a place (à¤•à¤¹à¥€à¤‚ à¤¸à¥‡ à¤¦à¥‚à¤° à¤²à¥‡ à¤œà¤¾à¤¨à¤¾)
Leading â€“ showing direction or guiding (à¤¨à¥‡à¤¤à¤¾ à¤¬à¤¨à¤•à¤° à¤®à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨ à¤•à¤°à¤¨à¤¾)
